reviewText: After having played trough Brothers in Arms: Road to Hill 30 and Earned in Blood I can say: These (3) games have a solid way of telling you what happened with the 101st Airborne squad. This game shows you the scenario's from Road to Hill 30 trough the eyes of Joe Red" Hartsock. The game play is absolutely amazing and the immersion is phenomenal.\n\nThe enemies and the objectives in Earned in Blood are slightly better and harder
date:
I really recommend playing this game on "normal" or harder difficulty to really get the developer intended experience especially the tactical game play.

If you have the time you should definitely play the games from the Brothers in Arms franchise. (9/10)

PS: For people with field of view problems this is adjustable in the "user.ini" file located in the game directory."

Story Review (No spoiler):

first of all brothers in arms is something like metal gear solid and you should play them in order to understand the story otherwise you understand NOTHING at all about the game. watching on youtube + reading on wiki and things like that wont help you have to play it yourself to find out what is going on. the order is:

1. Road to hill 30
2. Earned in blood
3. Hell's highway

there is no spoiler for you here but you need to know one thing about the story, brothers in arms starts like a normal world war II story, you play as a man called Matthew Baker the squad leader of 13 soldiers, 13 fathers, 13 sons, 13 families.... 13 is not a lucky number! in Road to hill 30 you start the game some where near france after parachuting from your shut down airplane and then after a few missions 2 of your squad members die mysteriously and then story focuses on this question how they died?"
date: there is another member in your team called Joseph Hartsock
recommended: the squad leader of the  2nd squad in road to hill 30
hoursPlayed: in the first BiA you do not see this squad you only hear about them and see them in cutscenes but there are in no missions. in fact they are in same mission area as you are but they are operating in differnet part of the map which you only hear about in cutscenes of road to hill 30.\n\nIn Earned in blood you play as Joseph Hartsock the second squad leader and you play almost all missions from Road to hill 30 but in the eyes of Joseph Hartsock
voteText: he tells you a secret story of what really happened back in road to hill 30 however the question about how your two squad members died back in Road to hill 30 still remains unanswered. this question will be answered in Hell's Highway
helpfulPercent: and prepare some tissues because that game will make you cry and makes you extremely emotional."

reviewText:
Earned in Blood, just like the other two Brothers in Arms games, has an amazing story.

The three games combined are simply the greatest WWII games out there. Call of Duty 2, of course, was amazing for the African campaign. But Gearbox hold the title for recreating very important battles in the Normandy region in France. I mean, if you've played the games, then maybe you've seen the extras where pictures show how much detail they put into recreating the villages in Northern France. It's very remarkable.

The story, you play as Joe Hartstock, Red, in this one. Maybe you remembered him in Road to Hill 30. Well, this game takes place alongside Road to Hill 30 as Joe is recounting his actions to SLAMarshall, a war documentarian, recording the actions of combat troops for the military. Throughout the story, Joe sees his friends get injured, change their attitude during the war, and some of them unfortunately die. But that's war.

The audio design is unreal. My dad walked by when I was playing and noted how realistic the sounds were for the rifles and panzers. The soundtrack, too, is amazing. Basically, I'm biased as hell as I already love WWII anything, but the strong character development, friendship, and tactical elements make the Brothers in Arms games some of my favorites.

9.0/10
voteText: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Earned in Blood can be treated as a direct expansion to Road to Hill 30. Using the same type of elements, EiB continuous the unique tactical-FPS that the Brothers in Arms series offers. EiB offers greater diversity in environments and has limited expansions in squad commands. If you own and enjoyed Road to Hill 30 then Earned in Blood is a must.

reviewText: Broters in Arms: Earned in Blood is Brothers in Arms: Road to Hill 30 with a different story. Nothing has been added or improved mechanic-wise, but at least nothing has been taken out or made worse. It's a nice little expansion pack, but for a sequel, it's hardly recommendable. But you will still like it if you liked Road to Hill 30, and haven't been burned out on it. It's also 2014, so price is cheap anyway.

reviewText: My nostalgia ruined Road to Hill 30 for me, as I have in a much longer review than this one. But Earned in Blood turned out to live up to it. Even though the game came out within the same year (just over half a year later) as Road to Hill 30, I think it turned out much better. I enjoy the general setup over Hartsock detailing his events and perspectives. I cannot say much about the real-life people, obviously, but I find the execution of this game to be more involving.\n\nThe gameplay is essentially the same, but the level environments are slightly more developed and lively in comparison to the first game. I know that the games are said to be very realistic, but the first game seems to be more sparse in what you encountered. Further, Earned in Blood has a lot more capability of using the Four F's, whereas Road to Hill 30 did not as much.
voteText: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Brothers in Arms: Earned in Blood delivers the same authentic, tactical World War 2 squad-based action found in the previous game, Road to Hill 30.

Earned in Blood introduces some non-story game modes, as well as new levels and story to the classic Brothers in Arms singleplayer campaign. The campaign itself - the main part of this game - is full of memorable characters and an immersive, interesting story.

If you're into anything World War 2, Brothers in Arms: Earned in Blood (or the previous Road to Hill 30) would be a game to try.
voteText: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
NOTE: If you haven't already, I highly recommend you play the first game (Brothers in Arms: Road to Hill 30) before playing this title.


Overview
The sequel to Road to Hill 30, the story is carried on by Joseph Red" Hartsock who is reflecting on the previous 15 days in Normandy with Colonel S.L.A Marshall (the guy Mac said was coming to interview them at the end of Road to Hill 30).

Story
The story follows Red
date: as he tells Colonel Marshall about his days fighting in Normandy from the drop all the way up until the seizing of Saint Sauveur Le Vicomte on D-Day +15. It's mixed between cutscenes of Red and Marshall talking or conversations off screen at the beggining of missions or in quiet moments. Many old faces pop up again
recommended: including old references and very interesting moments where you get to see what happened whilst you were off playing as Baker in the previous title. The game stays true in general to the campaign in Normandy
hoursPlayed:
and most of the battles/missions in this game were really fought during the second world war. The story is very intense and emotional in some places and succeeds like the previous game in showing the horror and violence of war.

Gameplay
Earned in Blood is essentially the same core gameplay as the previous game
voteText: using the Four F's (Find
votesHelpful: Flank and Finish.) You have two squads
votesFunny: and the Assualt team. You can command them to follow you
commentsCount: move to locations that you choose
column16:
suppress an enemy and even charge an enemy. One of the main HUD aspects is the suppression indicator on top of the enemies' heads. Red means unsuppressed and grey means suppressed and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ their pants. The basic method of overcoming enemies according to the game is to:

1. Get your Fire team to suppress the enemy.
2. Take you Assault team around and flank the enemy.
3. Once you are at the enemies' flank
column17: rek them.\n\nAlthough this is the barebones method
column18: a lot of the time it isn't that simple. I came into this title expecting it to be the exact same combat as the previous game
column19: but Gearbox have managed to switch it up a bit
column20: with improved AI that will react to your tactical descisions
column22: if you flank the enemy and they know this is happening
column23: they reposition themselves so they are protected and are safer from you/your men. That being said
column24: I still did see some of the silly AI appearing like in the previous game
column25: for example you order your men to take cover from an MG and they end up running around the cover and standing in plain sight. Also
column26: there are some pathing issues which can lead to some annoying squad wipes. The guns sights sway like hell
column27: so you will still find yourself missing easy shots although there are two new guns (Grease Gun
column28: Scoped FG42) which can lead to some interesting firefights. Another addition to the game are the Flak 88's. These bad boys are a nightmare to go up against and can prove a real challenge
column29: especially when multitasking in battle.  Unfortunately
column30:
the game doesn't have much of a replay value unless you are ok with replaying on a harder difficulty with less forgiving enemies and less HUD etc.

Map Design
Compared to Road to Hill 30
column31: Earned in Blood has really knocked it up a gear in terms of maps. While still slightly linear (hard not to be in this genre) they are a lot more expansive and give you more options in terms of attack and flanking. Also
column32: the game no longer stays in a green-french-rollinghills type of landscape and occasionally offers a change of scene with city combat
column33: which is quite fun and engaging with all of the flank routes. This
column34: combined with the better AI can lead to some challenging moments.\n\nGraphics
column35: Animations and Sound\nEarned in Blood's graphics
column36: animations and sound are pretty much identical if not exactly the same as the previous game. Textures are a bit murky and lip sync is not alway in time or accurate. The sound is very good in most cases
column37: apart from some anomalies for example VERY MINOR SPOILER:(When you are attacked by the convoy of Germans and their loud horsies
column38: the sound of the hooves is kinda loud and not in any general direction.) The soundtrack
column39: like all Brothers in Arms games is fantastic and always sets the mood just right and makes emotional scenes just that bit more sadder. Although the graphics and animations are well below today's standards
column40:
this shouldn't be a problem unless you are somebody who only plays games for the high end visuals and not for the great gameplay and story.

Extras
The game has many rewards for completing each mission
column41: and the higher the difficulty level on which you complete the level
column42: the more you unlock. Some of the things you unlock are real documents written by Colonel S.L.A Marshall about the interviews with soldiers
column43: historic and de-classified documents about the conflict
column46:
and even cheats for the game like infinite ammo and super squads etc. It's worth the extra difficulty for the rewards in my opinion.

Verdict
Overall this game is fantastic and just as good as the previous game

reviewText:
This series is, along with OpFor, proof that Gearbox isn't the worst developer on the planet Earth.

They may be pathological liars, but they ♥♥♥♥ up when a production of theirs is outsourced, half-♥♥♥♥♥ from the get go or largely NOT theirs (the last two apply to Duke Forever, the first to Aliens: Colonial Marines). They don't ♥♥♥♥ up when they're trying.

While I believe certain games like Borderlands can result in a loss of interest fairly quickly, it's still not a 'bad' game - just average.

The BIA series is about twenty times better than that. It's been a while since I've played through them all thoroughly, including Hell's Highway, during a completely different era and time period, but my memories of the games are good ones.

reviewText: Earned in Blood is very realistic and the combat features are superb, It's great that you have to take damage into account unlike CoD where you get shot and your health regenerates, so you have to been more tactical which is meant to enhance you strategic ability, and this applies to those you command during missions. And unlike CoD ammo conservation is key you can spray bullets and knowing you have hundreds of rounds in reserve, you only have a few clips. This game is focussed around real time combat strategy and when you run from place to place this makes you aim less accurrately and takes time to recover. The team you command during missions must be used effectively to complete the mission. This game I'd say on a level of realism is higher than CoD (by far) and slightly below Arma. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys FPS and stragey based games. And throws you into the events of the days both before and after D-day and is historically accurate.

reviewText: Brother in Arms: Earned in Blood is a classic WWII first person shooter. The graphic is dated but that is to be expected for any game from before “Modern Warfare’s” era. The story in-game tells a fantastic tale about a solider behind enemy lines.  The very nice voice acting only adds to the immersive experience. One original feature in this game is the ability to zoom out in to tactics mode and analyze the battlefield, this allows for alternative strategies and less linear gameplay. Beating missions with impressive performance will unlock additional fictional history about the in game characters, as well as other small bonuses. I had a few gripes with this game. The game is stupidly over scripted; your experience will not change at all with a second play through, using different strategies and routes can lead to some problems such as un-jumpable ledges, un-jumpable fences, and other stupid obstacles blocking what appears to be “jumpable” in any other game.

reviewText:
Nice ''sequel'' of sorts to RtH30 through the eyes of a different squadmate.
This could be considered it's downfall however as there are only a few chapters that really continue on the squad's collective story and instead focus' on Red's story.
Some great moments in this game but it doesn't really add anything new to the game (they were released a year apart) and it could be skipped without missing out on too much that it will affect a Hell's Highway playthrough.

Would still recommend if you enjoyed both the gameplay and story in RtH30!

reviewText: Story and the concept of the game are good. This game has some major issues though. The Allied AI is atrocious and causes a great deal of frustration, furthermore the game is riddled with artificial difficulty. A good example of this is the fact that a lot of times when you clearly should have hit an enemy you actually miss. This is mainly an issue if you try to for example shoot an enemy in the head when he pops out of cover. I guess is a way to force you to use the flanking mechanics the game has, but it's still very frustrating.\n\nIf you want a good Brothers in Arms game get Hell's Highway.

reviewText: This is a sequel that does what the original game did gameplay-wise, only better and slightly more refined in every way. The story runs parallel to the first game through the perspective of Hartsock, one of Baker's squadmates from the original game, and while the sotry is not as hard hitting and the characters aren't as interesting as in the original, the squadmate deaths are still some of the most powerful I've experienced in a game to date, arguably more powerful than in the first game (still with little to no character development, surprisingly). The tactical squad-based gameplay is still probably the best of any WW2 shooter to date, ignoring its sequel which improved on the same formula even more.

reviewText: The sequel to one of the greatest WWII games of all time.  The game play is exactly the same as in Road to Hill 30.  I did not feel Hartsock's story as genuinely as I did Baker's, but the same characters that we love are back.  The maps were larger and the AI was a bit better.  I think the missions were more difficult and exhausting (and sometimes more frustrating).\n\nI made a mod for this game, with tons of new features including improved AI, multiplayer bots, and new soldiers to help your squad.
